questions.text: What is true about the image below?

options.label: A
options.text: They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells along the path of electric current.

options.label: B
options.text: They indicate the path taken by the discharge along the major blood vessels

options.label: D
options.text: They gradually fade within 24 – 48 hours if the person is dead

questions.correct_answer: A. They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells along the path of electric current.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells along the path of electric current.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lichtenberg figures are caused by the staining of superficial tissues with hemoglobin after electrical injury from a lightning strike. These patterns are not burns and follow the path of microvasculature, not major blood vessels.

questions.text: True about the below image:

options.label: A
options.text: Heat stiffening due to ATP depletion

options.label: B
options.text: Protein coagulation due to heat stroke

options.label: C
options.text: Can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem burns

questions.correct_answer: C. Can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem burns
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem burns

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pugilistic attitude (or boxer’s attitude) is caused by heat-induced protein coagulation, leading to stiffening of the muscles. It can occur in both antemortem and postmortem burns, regardless of when the burns were sustained.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male construction worker is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at a worksite on a particularly hot afternoon. He appeared confused and irritable. His rectal temperature was recorded as 41.2°C (106.2°F). He is found to have rapid, shallow breathing. His pulse is 140 beats per minute, blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 30 breaths per minute. Which of the following is Likely in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Patient is aware that he has a high body temperature.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Patient can become unconscious

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In heat stroke, thermoregulatory failure results in the loss of awareness of body temperature and a lack of sweating. If untreated, it can lead to unconsciousness due to the extreme effects of heat on the brain.

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl was brought to the OPD. Genital examination revealed the findings as given below. Labia majora - separated Labia minora- flabby Fourchette tear present Roomy vagina seen with intact hymen What is true about this girl from the options below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) False virgin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A false virgin is someone who may have had sexual intercourse but retains an intact hymen due to its elasticity or thickness. Other signs, such as a roomy vagina and flabby labia minora, can indicate previous sexual activity even if the hymen remains intact.

questions.text: Police officer brings a 15-year-old male child to doctor for medical examination. Mother of the child gives the history that his uncle has been threatening and sexual assaulting him for past 2 years, which she came to know now and complained the police. After doing the complete examination, doctor examines the anus, which shows features as in the picture below. This is suggestive of?
questions.correct_answer: B. Repeated anal sex with child
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Repeated anal sex with child

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The loss of anal folds in a child can be a strong indicator of repeated anal sexual abuse.

questions.text: A mother delivers twins, but one baby has much larger development as compared to other. On DNA testing, only one of the twins matches the husband. What could be the cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Superfetation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superfetation refers to the conception of two fetuses in different menstrual cycles, resulting in twins with different levels of development. This condition can also explain differing DNA parentage for the twins.

questions.text: A 48-year-old forensic examiner is presented with a set of preserved clothing articles from a case that is 4 months old. Suspicion arises regarding the presence of aged seminal stains on the fabric. To establish the presence of semen, especially considering the potential degradation of the sample over time, which of the following biochemical tests should the examiner prioritize to yield reliable results?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Creatine phosphokinase test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For aged seminal stains (such as stains preserved for several months), creatine phosphokinase is the most reliable test for confirming the presence of semen, as it remains effective even after prolonged periods.
  • ➤ Key Points:
  • ➤ Key Points:
  • ➤ Presumptive tests like the acid phosphatase test are highly sensitive but can give false-positive results and are less reliable for aged stains. Confirmatory tests such as the CPK test and P30 test provide more reliable and specific results, especially for older seminal stains. Microscopic sperm detection is highly specific but relies on the presence of intact sperm cells, which may degrade over time.
  • ➤ Presumptive tests like the acid phosphatase test are highly sensitive but can give false-positive results and are less reliable for aged stains.
  • ➤ Presumptive tests
  • ➤ acid phosphatase test
  • ➤ Confirmatory tests such as the CPK test and P30 test provide more reliable and specific results, especially for older seminal stains.
  • ➤ Confirmatory tests
  • ➤ CPK test
  • ➤ P30 test
  • ➤ Microscopic sperm detection is highly specific but relies on the presence of intact sperm cells, which may degrade over time.
  • ➤ Microscopic sperm detection

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is found unresponsive in his apartment with multiple bloodstains on his clothing. The first responders to the scene need to determine whether the bloodstains are recent or if some might have been present for a longer period. Which method should the forensic team use to confirm the presence of blood in both the recent and older stains on the clothing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Spectroscopic test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The spectroscopic test is the most reliable confirmatory method to detect blood in both recent and old stains, as it identifies blood based on its unique absorption spectrum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is involved in a custody dispute and undergoes a forensic evaluation to establish the paternity of her child. The forensic scientist plans to use a bodily fluid for ABO blood typing, as the child is suspected to have inherited the secretor status from the parents. Which of the following bodily fluids is least likely to be suitable for ABO blood group determination in secretors?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In secretors, ABO blood group antigens can be found in most body fluids like saliva, semen, and tears, but not in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) , making it unsuitable for blood typing.
  • ➤ not in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual diagnosed with schizophrenia commits an act that would otherwise be considered a criminal offense. The act was committed during a period of acute psychotic episode. The individual's medical history indicates sporadic adherence to prescribed antipsychotic medication. The prosecution has charged the individual with the offense. Based on the provided information, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the criminal responsibility of mentally ill?

options.label: A
options.text: The accused will be responsible since the act was committed while not adhering to prescribed medication.

options.label: B
options.text: The accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.

options.label: C
options.text: The accused will be responsible due to the sporadic nature of the individual's symptoms.

options.label: D
options.text: The accused will not be responsible only if the act was committed during a state of complete unconsciousness.

questions.correct_answer: B. The accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An individual suffering from a severe mental illness like schizophrenia may not be held criminally responsible if they were incapable of understanding the nature of their actions or distinguishing between right and wrong at the time of the offense, as per the McNaughton Rule.

questions.text: Psychological autopsy is?

options.label: A
options.text: Autopsy of brain and spinal cord

options.label: B
options.text: To inquire about the psychiatric illnesses of the deceased

options.label: C
options.text: Assessment of the mental state of deceased person before death

questions.correct_answer: C. Assessment of the mental state of deceased person before death
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Assessment of the mental state of deceased person before death

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A psychological autopsy is a method used to assess the mental state of a deceased individual prior to their death, often to investigate the circumstances surrounding suspected suicides .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: The following documents are exceptions to oral evidence in court:

options.label: B
options.text: Dying declaration if the victim survived

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reports of Fingerprint Bureau

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reports from technical or forensic bodies, such as the Fingerprint Bureau , are exceptions to oral evidence in court because they are based on objective scientific analysis, leaving little room for subjective interpretation.

questions.text: During a late-night shift in a district hospital's emergency department, a medical officer is urgently called to attend to a patient with critical injuries from a hit-and-run accident. As the patient's condition deteriorates rapidly, the medical officer realizes the importance of recording the patient's account of the incident, suspecting it might be the patient's dying declaration. Given the urgency of the situation and the legal significance of the patient's statement, which of the following actions aligns best with the protocol for recording a dying declaration in India?

options.label: A
options.text: The medical officer must wait for the presence of the accused and their lawyer before recording the patient's statement.

options.label: B
options.text: The medical officer can record the patient's statement only if the magistrate is present.

options.label: C
options.text: The medical officer is allowed to ask leading questions to quickly gather all necessary information from the patient.

options.label: D
options.text: If the patient unexpectedly recovers, the recorded statement will lose its value

questions.correct_answer: D. If the patient unexpectedly recovers, the recorded statement will lose its value
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) If the patient unexpectedly recovers, the recorded statement will lose its value

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In India, a dying declaration can be recorded by any responsible person, including a medical officer, and does not require the presence of the accused or cross-examination. However, if the patient recovers, the dying declaration loses its legal standing.

questions.text: A 32-year-old women married for 5 years was found deceased under suspicious circumstances in a rented apartment in Mumbai. The case has drawn significant media attention, and there is pressure on authorities to conduct a thorough investigation. According to the Indian legal process, which type of inquest will be done?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Magistrate inquest

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For cases involving dowry deaths in India, which include deaths under suspicious circumstances within 7 years of marriage, a magistrate inquest is required.

questions.text: Dr. Singh, a cardiologist in New Delhi, is under investigation after several complaints from patients regarding his prescription practices, which allegedly violate the nationally recognized medical code of ethics. He is accused of overprescribing medications in exchange for incentives from a pharmaceutical company. In the context of medical regulation in India, to which authority can Dr singh appeal if he is punished by state medical council?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Central Health Ministry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If a doctor is punished by the State Medical Council, they can appeal the decision to the Central Health Ministry , which takes advice from the National Medical Commission.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy Gautam is accused of causing a grievous hurt to an elderly man in his neighborhood. The case of Gautam will be tried in a juvenile court which has a Juvenile justice board. Which of the following is true with respect to composition of juvenile justice board?

options.label: A
options.text: Three Social workers of which two must be women

options.label: C
options.text: Judicial Magistrate of first class who must be a woman

questions.correct_answer: B. Judicial Magistrate of first class
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Judicial Magistrate of first class

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Juvenile Justice Board consists of a Judicial Magistrate of the first class and two social workers, with at least one of the social workers being a woman. There is no requirement for the magistrate to be female.

questions.text: A patient is brought into the emergency room after a severe car accident. The patient is unconscious and in critical condition, with multiple injuries. In this situation, the healthcare team may need to perform various surgical procedures, such as: Emergency surgery to stop internal bleeding. Orthopedic surgery to repair broken bones. Neurosurgery to relieve pressure on the brain. Plastic surgery to address facial injuries. Thoracic surgery to treat lung injuries. The healthcare team explains all the risks and different types of surgeries that will be required for multiple injuries. This is a type of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Informed consent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Informed consent involves providing the patient or their legal guardian with comprehensive information about the medical procedures and risks involved, allowing them to make an informed decision about their treatment.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For permanent teeth:
  • ➤ First molars typically erupt between 6-7 years. Lateral incisors erupt between 8-9 years. Canines erupt between 11-12 years. Third molars (wisdom teeth) erupt between 17-25 years.
  • ➤ First molars typically erupt between 6-7 years.
  • ➤ Lateral incisors erupt between 8-9 years.
  • ➤ Canines erupt between 11-12 years.
  • ➤ Third molars (wisdom teeth) erupt between 17-25 years.

questions.text: Which of the following feature is related to the mandible of female ?
questions.correct_answer: A. Angle of ramus- More obtuse
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Angle of ramus- More obtuse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The student must memorize that the angle of the mandible in females is more obtuse compared to males, who have sharper, more prominent mandible features.
  • ➤ angle of the mandible in females is more obtuse

questions.text: A skull was recovered from a forest. According to inquest papers, woman had gone missing after a fight with her boyfriend a month back. The skull was sent to the forensic research lab. Which of the following would identify it as a female skull? Prominent external occipital protuberance Heavy cheek bones Square orbits Large mastoid
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Female skulls are generally characterized by smaller, more rounded features, including rounder orbits, less prominent occipital protuberances, and smaller mastoid processes. The features listed in the question are typically male traits.

questions.text: A forensic anthropologist is examining a set of skeletal remains discovered at an archaeological site. The mandible is relatively well preserved. The focus is on determining the sex of the individual based on the mandible. Which of the following features will be found in male mandible as compared to female mandible?

options.label: A
options.text: Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: B
options.text: Round Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: C
options.text: Square Chin, more obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: D
options.text: Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, smaller body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

questions.correct_answer: A. Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Male mandibles are characterized by a square chin, a less obtuse angle, greater body height at the symphysis, and a broader ascending ramus, making them more robust compared to female mandible

questions.text: If a doctor receives summon from more than one court simultaneously, which rule should be followed:

options.label: A
options.text: Criminal court have priority over civil court

options.label: B
options.text: Higher court have priority over lower court

options.label: C
options.text: Civil court have priority over criminal court

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both A and B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The student should memorize that when receiving summons from multiple courts simultaneously, priority should be given to criminal courts over civil courts and higher courts over lower courts .
  • ➤ priority should be given to criminal courts over civil courts
  • ➤ higher courts over lower courts

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Marshall’s triad in relation to explosive injuries?

options.label: A
options.text: Marshall's triad consists of burns, fractures, and internal bleeding.

options.label: B
options.text: Marshall's triad includes fractures, dislocations, and bone bruises.

options.label: C
options.text: Marshall's triad refers to bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations.

options.label: D
options.text: Marshall's triad consists of head trauma, chest trauma, and abdominal trauma.

questions.correct_answer: C. Marshall's triad refers to bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Marshall's triad refers to bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marshall's triad in explosive injuries refers to the combination of bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations caused by small, high-velocity fragments in secondary blast injuries.

questions.text: A gunshot case brought for autopsy shows an entry wound with inverted margins and the wound is surrounded by blackening and tattooing. Singed burnt hair was noted. What is the range of the weapon?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Close contact

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of blackening, tattooing, and singed hair indicates that the gunshot was fired at close contact range , where the muzzle is close to but not in tight contact with the skin.
  • ➤ close contact range

questions.text: The post-mortem examination of a body shows transverse intimal tears on the carotid artery as below. What could be the most probable cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hanging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transverse intimal tears in the carotid artery (Amussat's sign) are strongly indicative of death due to hanging.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man was found deceased in his living room, suspended by a rope from the ceiling fan. The knot was tied to the right side of his neck. The scene was secured and examined by a forensic expert from the local medical college, who noted several findings consistent with hanging. The body showed signs of lividity in the lower extremities, and there was noticeable constriction around the neck caused by the ligature. During the examination, the forensic expert observed a distinctive pattern of salivary staining. Based on the positioning of the knot and the principles of forensic medicine, where would the dribbling of saliva most likely be found in this case of atypical hanging?

options.label: A
options.text: Towards the site of the knot

options.label: B
options.text: Opposite the site of the knot

options.label: C
options.text: At both angles of the mouth

questions.correct_answer: B. Opposite the site of the knot
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Opposite the site of the knot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of hanging, salivary dribbling usually occurs opposite to the side of the knot , which is a sign of antemortem hanging.
  • ➤ opposite to the side of the knot

questions.text: In a gripping episode of a forensic investigation TV series, the protagonist, a seasoned forensic expert, is called to a picturesque but remote lakeside campsite where a tragic incident occurred. A young camper was found unresponsive in the shallow waters near the shore early in the morning. Initial suspicions pointed towards an accidental drowning, but the expert's keen observations suggest there might be more to the story. As the investigation unfolds, the forensic expert explains the critical nuances of freshwater drowning to the investigative team, focusing on the physiological effects that could lead to fatal outcomes. The team is particularly interested in understanding the mechanism behind the sudden cardiac arrest observed in the victim. What is the most likely cause of ventricular fibrillation in this case of freshwater drowning?

options.label: A
options.text: Total asphyxia induced by the panic and struggle in water

options.label: B
options.text: Cold water shock leading to involuntary laryngeal spasm

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid fluid shifts causing blood thickening and clot formation

options.label: D
options.text: Hemodilution from absorbed freshwater, leading to an electrolyte imbalance

questions.correct_answer: D. Hemodilution from absorbed freshwater, leading to an electrolyte imbalance
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hemodilution from absorbed freshwater, leading to an electrolyte imbalance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In freshwater drowning, water absorption through the lungs into the bloodstream leads to hemodilution and electrolyte imbalances , particularly hyperkalemia , which can result in ventricular fibrillation and sudden cardiac arrest.
  • ➤ hemodilution
  • ➤ electrolyte imbalances
  • ➤ hyperkalemia
  • ➤ ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: Identify the gestational age of the fetus if the Crown Rump Length is 21 cm. Both testes are seen near the external inguinal ring. The gestational age of the fetus will be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 7 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The position of the testes can be a key indicator of fetal gestational age. In this case, both testes near the external inguinal ring suggest a gestational age of 7 months .
  • ➤ 7 months

questions.text: Dead Body of fetus was found submerged in water by a local fisherman. The crown heel length was found to be 25 cm, and length of lower limbs was 10 cm. Few hairs were present on his body and ossification center of calcaneum was present. Approximate age of the fetus is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 5 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fetus with a crown-heel length of 25 cm and the ossification center of the calcaneum present is approximately 5 months in gestational age.
  • ➤ 5 months

questions.text: A dead born foetus does not have?

options.label: C
options.text: Rigor mortis if gestational age is < 7 months

questions.correct_answer: C. Rigor mortis if gestational age is < 7 months
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rigor mortis if gestational age is < 7 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rigor mortis does not occur in dead-born fetuses with a gestational age less than 7 months, while overcrowding of ribs can occur due to maceration.
  • ➤ Rigor mortis does not occur
  • ➤ overcrowding of ribs

questions.text: A baby is still born in the hospital, but still has signs of respiration. Which is true in this context?

options.label: A
options.text: This might be a case vagitus vaginalis

options.label: B
options.text: This might be a case of vagitus uterinus

options.label: C
options.text: Can occur due to forceps delivery

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both A and B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to be memorized is that vagitus vaginalis and vagitus uterinus are rare conditions in which a baby may cry and show signs of respiration while still in the vagina or uterus, even if the baby is ultimately stillborn.
  • ➤ vagitus vaginalis
  • ➤ vagitus uterinus

questions.text: During a heated altercation in a public space, an individual is accused of physically assaulting another person, resulting in the victim sustaining a broken mandible. The incident, witnessed by several bystanders, prompts immediate police intervention. Given the severity of the injury and the circumstances surrounding the altercation, what action are the police most likely authorized to take against the accused individual?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arrest without warrant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to remember is that grievous hurt , such as a broken mandible, is a cognizable offense . This allows the police to arrest the accused without a warrant due to the serious nature of the injury.
  • ➤ grievous hurt
  • ➤ cognizable offense

questions.text: Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Code for punishment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to memorize is that Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) is the revised form of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and primarily deals with the definition of crimes and their punishments .
  • ➤ Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS)
  • ➤ Indian Penal Code (IPC)
  • ➤ definition of crimes and their punishments

questions.text: Police officers found a completely burnt dead body of a person in a forest. They suspect that someone might have killed him and later burnt the dead body to avoid identification. Image of victim is shown below. This is suggestive of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Either A or B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to learn is that heat ruptures can resemble lacerations or incised wounds and can occur in both antemortem and postmortem burns . These skin splits happen due to high heat, without blood vessel or nerve damage from mechanical force.
  • ➤ heat ruptures
  • ➤ antemortem
  • ➤ postmortem burns

questions.text: Characteristic of Joule burn include all except?

options.label: B
options.text: Joule burn is not hyperaemic or only little bit hyperaemic

options.label: C
options.text: Pale raised skin at the margins

options.label: D
options.text: Can be seen at places other than electric contact point

questions.correct_answer: D. Can be seen at places other than electric contact point
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Can be seen at places other than electric contact point

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to memorize is that Joule burns occur only at the point of contact with an electrical source, typically resulting in a round or oval shallow crater with pale raised margins and minimal hyperemia . They do not appear in areas other than the contact point.
  • ➤ Joule burns
  • ➤ only at the point of contact
  • ➤ round or oval shallow crater
  • ➤ pale raised margins
  • ➤ minimal hyperemia

questions.text: During an autopsy conducted by a forensic expert at a medical college, the body of a 40-year-old man who died in a hospital is examined. The man was initially hospitalized following a car accident. The autopsy reveals that the man had a pre-existing medical condition that was exacerbated by a delayed surgery due to hospital administrative errors. Additionally, it is found that the man had not been wearing a seatbelt at the time of the accident. In this context, which type of negligence would involve the concept of 'contributory negligence' as a defense?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Civil negligence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to remember is that contributory negligence is a defense that applies in cases of civil negligence , where both the injured party and another party (such as a hospital or doctor) may share responsibility for the injury. It is not used in criminal or corporate negligence cases.
  • ➤ contributory negligence
  • ➤ civil negligence

questions.text: You are a resident performing a postmortem examination under the supervision of the medical examiner. The body of a recently deceased individual shows several physiological changes. As part of your training, you are asked to identify the findings that are not typically associated with the early postmortem period. Which of the following is not considered an early sign of death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Loss of voluntary power

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to remember is that loss of voluntary power is an immediate sign of death, not an early postmortem change. Early postmortem signs include changes like corneal opacity , loss of skin elasticity , and postmortem cooling (algor mortis) .
  • ➤ loss of voluntary power
  • ➤ immediate sign
  • ➤ corneal opacity
  • ➤ loss of skin elasticity
  • ➤ postmortem cooling (algor mortis)

questions.text: During a training session in forensic medicine, a resident learns about the importance of analyzing the vitreous humor in determining the postmortem interval. Which constituent of the vitreous humor is most helpful in accurately estimating the postmortem interval?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) K

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to remember is that potassium (K) levels in the vitreous humor increase steadily for about 100 hours postmortem , making it the most helpful constituent in accurately estimating the postmortem interval .
  • ➤ potassium (K) levels in the vitreous humor
  • ➤ 100 hours postmortem
  • ➤ postmortem interval

questions.text: A nurse in a private clinic was found to have administered the wrong medication to a patient due to a misreading of the prescription, resulting in the patient's death. The legal proceedings against the nurse is based on the charge of causing death by negligence. What is the maximum punishment that can be imposed on the Nurse for this act of medical negligence?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to memorize is that under Section 106 of the Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita (formerly Section 304A of IPC) , the maximum punishment for medical negligence resulting in death is 2 years of imprisonment .
  • ➤ Section 106 of the Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita (formerly Section 304A of IPC)
  • ➤ medical negligence resulting in death
  • ➤ 2 years of imprisonment

questions.text: Which of the following is secondary blast injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Rapid increase in pressure, damaging hollow organs.

options.label: B
options.text: Injury caused by airborne debris, resulting in Marshall’s triad injuries.

options.label: C
options.text: Victim being thrown into the air by the blast wind.

options.label: D
options.text: Respiratory injuries due to toxic gases and dust.

questions.correct_answer: B. Injury caused by airborne debris, resulting in Marshall’s triad injuries.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Injury caused by airborne debris, resulting in Marshall’s triad injuries.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A secondary blast injury is caused by debris and shrapnel thrown by the explosion, which can lead to significant trauma, including penetrating injuries. Understanding the distinctions between the types of blast injuries is crucial for proper diagnosis and treatment in blast-related incidents.
  • ➤ secondary blast injury

questions.text: The phenomenon known as "Washerwoman's hand," characterized by wrinkled and pale appearance of the skin on the hands and feet, is most indicative of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Submersion in water

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ "Washerwoman's hand" is a sign of submersion in water and occurs due to the skin's prolonged exposure to moisture. It is important to distinguish this phenomenon as a result of water exposure, not necessarily as an indication of drowning or decomposition.
  • ➤ "Washerwoman's hand"

questions.text: The drowned dead body of a young man found in the sea and was brought in for postmortem examination. Which of the following findings do you see in seawater drowning? Hypernatremia Hyponatremia Hyperkalemia Myocardial anoxia Hemodilution
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In seawater drowning, the main findings are hypernatremia (due to the high salt content in seawater) and myocardial anoxia (due to asphyxia). Understanding these distinctions helps in identifying the type of drowning and the physiological changes that occur.
  • ➤ hypernatremia
  • ➤ myocardial anoxia

questions.text: A concerned mother takes her daughter of 14 years age who was complaining of pain in the private parts to a gynecologist. On eliciting history, the girl admits she had consensual sexual intercourse with a neighbor. She is 21 weeks pregnant. Which one is true? Take a vaginal Swab MTP cannot be done unless serious congenital anomaly is found Consent of medical board required for MTP No need to inform the police if the victim and mother don’t wish to file a police complaint
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None are true

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases involving minors under the age of 18, sexual activity is always considered statutory rape. Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) is allowed for cases of rape up to 24 weeks, and police must always be informed in such cases. For pregnancies between 20 and 24 weeks, MTP can be performed with the consent of two doctors, without the need for a medical board, unless the pregnancy is beyond 24 weeks.

questions.text: A forensic expert is reviewing autopsy reports for a series of asphyxiation cases. In the course of this review, the expert is aware that certain methods of asphyxiation carry a higher suspicion of homicidal intent due to their nature and the circumstances under which they typically occur. Which method of asphyxiation listed below is almost always considered to be homicidal in nature?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gagging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gagging is most commonly considered homicidal due to the intent and force involved in obstructing the airway, usually in conjunction with restraint or violent acts. Recognizing the type of asphyxiation involved helps forensic experts determine the likelihood of foul play.
  • ➤ Gagging

questions.text: A person was found dead on road side. On examination there was cyanosis of the nails, scratches over face, neck and chin, and laceration near lips. Which of the following is not the probable mode of death in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Case of a suicide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases involving injuries to the face and neck with signs of asphyxia, the likelihood of homicidal death due to smothering or throttling is high. Such injuries are rarely seen in cases of suicide, making homicide a much more probable conclusion in this context.
  • ➤ homicidal
  • ➤ smothering or throttling

questions.text: A 55-year-old male prisoner, sentenced to death, underwent execution by judicial hanging. The execution was performed with a calculated drop length. Upon autopsy, the forensic expert observed a specific finding with no signs of struggle or defensive injuries. Considering the mechanism of death in judicial hangings and the autopsy findings, what is the most likely cause of death in this case?
questions.correct_answer: C. Fracture of upper cervical vertebra
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fracture of upper cervical vertebra

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Judicial hanging typically results in death due to a fracture of the upper cervical vertebrae (C2-C3), known as the hangman’s fracture , which causes instant death by severing the spinal cord and disrupting brainstem functions. Understanding the mechanism of death is critical in differentiating judicial hanging from other forms of asphyxiation.
  • ➤ Judicial hanging
  • ➤ fracture of the upper cervical vertebrae
  • ➤ hangman’s fracture

questions.text: In the context of forensic age determination, ossification centers play a pivotal role. At what stage of development do the earliest centers of ossification appear?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5-6 weeks.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first ossification center appears in the body of the clavicle at around 5-6 weeks of intrauterine life. Understanding ossification timelines is essential in forensic age estimation, as different bones ossify and fuse at various stages of development.
  • ➤ first ossification center
  • ➤ 5-6 weeks

questions.text: A 20-year-old unmarried girl was brought to the OPD. Genital examination revealed the findings as given below. Labia majora - separated Labia minora- flabby Old ruptured hymen Deep, roomy, dilated and capacious with less rugosed wall What is true about this girl from the options below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Not a virgin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In forensic examinations, the status of the hymen and other genital findings provide clues to assess sexual history, but virginity cannot always be conclusively determined based on physical examination alone. In this case, the girl is not a virgin based on the described findings.
  • ➤ not a virgin

questions.text: Disputed maternity can be solved by using the following tests except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Precipitin test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DNA fingerprinting is the confirmatory test for resolving disputed maternity, while the precipitin test is a species-specific test and cannot be used to determine biological relationships like maternity or paternity.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl, is brought by a lady police sub-inspector to the doctor, alleging a history of sexual violence that occurred in the morning same day. Which statement is incorrect as the next course of action by the doctor?

options.label: C
options.text: Consent of a legal guardian is not mandatory to give the medical treatment for injuries to the victim.

options.label: D
options.text: Consent of victim is sufficient, and that of legal guardian is not required for MTP if the girl is found to be pregnant at a later stage

questions.correct_answer: D. Consent of victim is sufficient, and that of legal guardian is not required for MTP if the girl is found to be pregnant at a later stage
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Consent of victim is sufficient, and that of legal guardian is not required for MTP if the girl is found to be pregnant at a later stage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For medical treatment following sexual violence, the consent of the victim is sufficient, but in cases involving minors, the legal guardian's consent is mandatory for MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy). Understanding the legal requirements for minors in medical situations is crucial for healthcare providers.
  • ➤ legal guardian's consent
  • ➤ mandatory

questions.text: Identical twins have similarities in all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fingerprint pattern

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identical twins have the same blood group , DNA , and often the same iris color , but their fingerprints are unique due to the influence of environmental factors during development.
  • ➤ blood group
  • ➤ DNA
  • ➤ iris color
  • ➤ fingerprints

questions.text: A child who is a victim under POCSO act is brought to the department of forensic medicine for age estimation. The X-ray image of the hand is shown below. What is the likely age of the child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 13 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In forensic age estimation using hand X-rays, the appearance of carpal bones is a key indicator. The pisiform bone is the last carpal bone to ossify, and its appearance suggests that the child is at least 10 to 12 years old. In this case, the most likely age is 13 years based on the full set of carpal bones observed.
  • ➤ pisiform
  • ➤ 13 years

questions.text: A rape victim is examined in a hospital and a specimen from her vagina is subjected to staining by 10% HCl, potassium iodide, iodine and water. Dark brown rhombic shaped crystals appear immediately. Which confirmatory test should be done, if the accused is azoospermic?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acid phosphatase test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of azoospermia, the acid phosphatase test is the confirmatory test used to detect the presence of seminal fluid. While Florence test and others are useful presumptive tests, confirmatory tests like acid phosphatase are necessary to establish the presence of semen in the absence of sperm cells.
  • ➤ acid phosphatase test
  • ➤ Florence test

questions.text: A naked man is caught in his room who has installed hidden camera in a neighbour’s room who is a 18 year old girl, and peeping into her bathroom and trying to watch the female inhabitant’s bathe. This sexual perversion is defined as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Voyeurism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Voyeurism involves secretly observing others for sexual gratification. It is crucial to distinguish between various forms of sexual deviance, such as voyeurism, exhibitionism, and frotteurism, based on the behavior and context involved.
  • ➤ Voyeurism

questions.text: During a high-profile court case, the jury is presented with the situation of a 40-year-old university professor who has been charged with the serious assault of a colleague. It comes to light during the trial that the professor has been battling untreated schizophrenia, characterized by profound auditory hallucinations and delusions. On the day in question, he was under the delusion that his colleague was a covert agent sent to harm him, leading to the assault. The defence argues that the professor's mental state at the time of the incident rendered him incapable of understanding his actions' nature or distinguishing right from wrong. Given these circumstances and applying the Legal Test of Insanity, how should the professor's criminal responsibility be assessed?

options.label: A
options.text: He is criminally responsible because he was conscious of his physical actions during the assault.

options.label: B
options.text: He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.

options.label: C
options.text: He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to control his actions due to his underlying schizophrenia.

options.label: D
options.text: He is criminally responsible because his mental illness does not excuse violent behavior.

questions.correct_answer: B. He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The McNaughton Rule forms the basis of legal insanity, focusing on whether a person could understand the nature of their actions or distinguish right from wrong. In this case, the professor’s schizophrenia and resulting delusions impaired his understanding, leading to a conclusion of no criminal responsibility due to legal insanity.
  • ➤ McNaughton Rule
  • ➤ no criminal responsibility

questions.text: In a rural clinic, a medical officer is faced with a case of acute poisoning. A 25-year-old patient has been brought in after ingesting an unknown substance at home. The medical officer needs to quickly administer an initial treatment to reduce the absorption of the poison. In preparing an emergency response, the medical officer considers the components of the universal antidote. Which of the following substances, commonly available in medical settings, is a part of this universal antidote and should be administered in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Activated charcoal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of unknown poisoning, activated charcoal is the most commonly used component of the universal antidote due to its ability to adsorb a wide range of toxins and prevent further absorption. It is important to initiate its use promptly in emergency poisoning cases.
  • ➤ activated charcoal

questions.text: A 25-year-old industrial worker was found dead at work place. He was working in a confined space near a decaying organic material storage facility for several hours since morning. Likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Methane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methane is a common gas produced by decaying organic matter in confined spaces, and it poses a significant risk due to its ability to displace oxygen. Recognizing the risk of methane and other sewer gases in such environments is essential for preventing occupational hazards in confined spaces.

questions.text: 18-year woman is having agitation, hallucinations, and nystagmus. She is also exhibiting muscle rigidity & occasional catatonic posturing. Likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Phencyclidine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication can cause a combination of symptoms, including agitation , hallucinations , nystagmus , muscle rigidity , and catatonic posturing . These signs, particularly the presence of nystagmus and muscle rigidity, help differentiate PCP from other hallucinogenic or stimulant substances. Recognizing these specific symptoms is essential in diagnosing PCP intoxication.
  • ➤ Phencyclidine (PCP)
  • ➤ agitation
  • ➤ hallucinations
  • ➤ nystagmus
  • ➤ muscle rigidity
  • ➤ catatonic posturing

questions.text: A 7-year-old child from an environment presents with pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL and a peripheral blood smear demonstrates a peculiar finding shown below. Which of the following differential diagnoses is most likely responsible for this finding in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis.

options.label: B
options.text: Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, leading to intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens.

options.label: D
options.text: Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

questions.correct_answer: D. Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of lead poisoning , enzymes involved in heme synthesis are inhibited, leading to basophilic stippling on a blood smear due to the accumulation of ribosomal material in red blood cells. This is a key diagnostic feature and should prompt further investigation for lead exposure, especially in children from environments where such exposure is common.
  • ➤ lead poisoning
  • ➤ heme synthesis
  • ➤ basophilic stippling

questions.text: 58 yr woman comes to emergency with blue skin, and headache. She does not complain of chest pain or dyspnoea. She Recently started on isosorbide nitrite 40 mg QID. Vitals normal, markedly cyanotic, has laboured respiration. 100% O2 does not help. Cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Methemoglobinemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methemoglobinemia is caused by the oxidation of hemoglobin to methemoglobin (Fe³⁺), which impairs oxygen delivery to tissues. It can be induced by drugs like isosorbide dinitrate and presents with cyanosis and headache , with no improvement after oxygen therapy. Recognizing this condition is important, as the treatment typically involves administration of methylene blue , which reduces methemoglobin back to functional hemoglobin.
  • ➤ Methemoglobinemia
  • ➤ isosorbide dinitrate
  • ➤ cyanosis
  • ➤ headache
  • ➤ methylene blue

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to ED in a coma with CPR in progress. A friend found him in the schoolyard. His friend confesses that the patient has been depressed over the past several days. His initial labs reveal hypocalcemia and a severe metabolic acidosis. The urine shows calcium oxalate crystals. What was the toxic ingestion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ethylene Glycol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethylene glycol poisoning leads to the production of oxalic acid , which binds to calcium and forms calcium oxalate crystals . This results in hypocalcemia , severe metabolic acidosis , and potential acute renal failure . Recognizing these characteristic findings is crucial for diagnosing ethylene glycol poisoning and initiating appropriate treatment, which includes fomepizole or ethanol to inhibit further metabolism of ethylene glycol.
  • ➤ Ethylene glycol poisoning
  • ➤ oxalic acid
  • ➤ calcium oxalate crystals
  • ➤ hypocalcemia
  • ➤ severe metabolic acidosis
  • ➤ acute renal failure
  • ➤ fomepizole
  • ➤ ethanol

questions.text: An approximately twenty-something year old female presents to the emergency department after she collapsed outside a bar. Physical Examination: T: 97.5°F HR: 60 bpm RR: 5 breaths per minute BP: 75/57 mm Hg Pupils are miotic but equal. Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation. CV: Regular rate and rhythm. Abdomen: Normal Neurologic: GCS = 6 (E1V1M4). Best treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Naloxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best treatment for a suspected opioid overdose is naloxone , which rapidly reverses the life-threatening effects of opioids, particularly respiratory depression and altered consciousness. Naloxone should be administered immediately in cases where opioid overdose is suspected, as it can be life-saving.
  • ➤ opioid overdose
  • ➤ naloxone
  • ➤ respiratory depression

questions.text: Amongst the options given below, which of these are not seen in cocaine poisoning?

options.label: A
options.text: Tingling and numbness of hands and feet

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Constricted pupils and bradycardia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cocaine poisoning is characterized by sympathomimetic effects such as tachycardia , mydriasis (dilated pupils) , hypertension , and hyperthermia . Constricted pupils (miosis) and bradycardia are not seen in cocaine poisoning and are more characteristic of opioid or cholinergic toxicity.
  • ➤ Cocaine poisoning
  • ➤ sympathomimetic effects
  • ➤ tachycardia
  • ➤ mydriasis (dilated pupils)
  • ➤ hypertension
  • ➤ hyperthermia
  • ➤ Constricted pupils (miosis)
  • ➤ bradycardia
  • ➤ opioid
  • ➤ cholinergic

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with agitation, dilated pupils, and tachycardia. He appears restless and paranoid, and he is sweating profusely. His blood pressure is elevated. What is the likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute Cocaine poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cocaine poisoning presents with sympathomimetic features such as agitation , tachycardia , dilated pupils , elevated blood pressure , and profuse sweating due to the inhibition of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin reuptake. Recognizing these signs is crucial in differentiating cocaine toxicity from other overdoses such as opioids or benzodiazepines, which typically cause CNS depression.
  • ➤ Cocaine poisoning
  • ➤ sympathomimetic features
  • ➤ agitation
  • ➤ tachycardia
  • ➤ dilated pupils
  • ➤ elevated blood pressure
  • ➤ profuse sweating

questions.text: Activated charcoal is ineffective in poisoning of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ethyl alcohol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Activated charcoal is ineffective in the treatment of ethyl alcohol poisoning because alcohol does not bind to charcoal. Activated charcoal is commonly used for various other poisonings, but it does not work for substances like alcohol, metals, organophosphates, and hydrocarbons. Recognizing when activated charcoal is appropriate or ineffective is essential in managing poisoning cases.
  • ➤ ineffective
  • ➤ ethyl alcohol poisoning

questions.text: A Casualty medical officer is called to assess a patient who has ingested a toxic substance. During the assessment, the medical officer observes that the patient's urine has turned green. This unusual symptom raises concerns about the specific toxic substance involved. Which toxic substance is most likely responsible for the green-colored urine seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phenol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Green-colored urine in a poisoning case is characteristic of phenol (carbolic acid) poisoning , which causes the breakdown products hydroquinone and pyrocatechol to be excreted in the urine. Recognizing such distinctive signs is important for the diagnosis and management of specific toxic ingestions.
  • ➤ Green-colored urine
  • ➤ phenol (carbolic acid) poisoning
  • ➤ hydroquinone
  • ➤ pyrocatechol

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of poisoning. He is conscious but in distress, and reports ingesting a substance about an hour ago. The medical officer notes a distinct smell from the patient's breath. Considering the nature of the substance ingested and the time since ingestion, the medical officer must decide on the appropriate decontamination procedure. For which of the following poisons, consistent with the patient's presentation, is gastric lavage particularly indicated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Carbolic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gastric lavage is contraindicated in most cases of corrosive poisoning due to the risk of perforation; however, it can be considered in carbolic acid poisoning because of its unique property of coagulative necrosis , which reduces the risk of perforation. Recognizing when gastric lavage is appropriate is crucial for managing poisoning cases safely.
  • ➤ Gastric lavage
  • ➤ carbolic acid poisoning
  • ➤ coagulative necrosis

questions.text: A person was brought to emergency with history of snake bite 8 hours ago. The patient had low respiratory rate and bradycardia with drooping of eyelids noted. 10 vials of antivenom were administered. What is the next line of management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Give atropine + neostigmine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of neurotoxic snake bites , presenting with symptoms like ptosis , bradycardia , and respiratory depression , the administration of atropine + neostigmine is critical after antivenom to reverse neurotoxic paralysis.
  • ➤ neurotoxic snake bites
  • ➤ ptosis
  • ➤ bradycardia
  • ➤ respiratory depression
  • ➤ atropine + neostigmine

questions.text: After visiting a village temple with his grandmother, a 5-year-old boy began crying intensely during the return trip. Within three hours, he was brought to the emergency department. He displayed symptoms such as altered consciousness, cold and sweaty extremities, heightened salivation, and excessive sweating. Physical examination revealed paleness and priapism, along with vital signs as follows: blood pressure of 140/78 mmHg, heart rate of 152 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Considering his condition, what treatment approach would you choose for his management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prazosin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of scorpion sting with symptoms of catecholamine excess (e.g., tachycardia , hypertension , priapism , excessive sweating ), the treatment of choice is prazosin to counteract the effects of the catecholamine surge. Recognizing these signs and treating promptly with the appropriate antidote is crucial to managing scorpion envenomation effectively.
  • ➤ scorpion sting
  • ➤ catecholamine excess
  • ➤ tachycardia
  • ➤ hypertension
  • ➤ priapism
  • ➤ excessive sweating
  • ➤ prazosin

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual presents to the emergency department with severe pain, restlessness, hypertension, tachycardia, and sweating after being stung by a scorpion. The sting site is red and swollen, with no signs of necrosis. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Apply a tourniquet proximal to the sting site

options.label: D
options.text: Cleanse the wound and apply ice packs

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Administer prazosin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients presenting with systemic symptoms of catecholamine excess after a scorpion sting , the primary treatment is prazosin . It effectively counters the adrenergic storm caused by the venom, leading to symptom resolution and stabilization.
  • ➤ catecholamine excess
  • ➤ scorpion sting
  • ➤ prazosin

questions.text: A 35-year industrial worker presents with severe burns on his hands and arms after a workplace accident. There are deep burns with extensive tissue dissolution. Burns appear slimy, slippery, and gelatinous. Likely responsible agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sodium hydroxide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alkalis like sodium hydroxide cause liquefactive necrosis , leading to deep tissue damage with a slimy and gelatinous appearance. In contrast, acids cause coagulative necrosis . Recognizing the type of necrosis can help in identifying the responsible chemical agent in burn injuries.
  • ➤ Alkalis
  • ➤ sodium hydroxide
  • ➤ liquefactive necrosis
  • ➤ slimy
  • ➤ gelatinous
  • ➤ coagulative necrosis

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had arching of his back. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Strychnine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Strychnine poisoning causes muscle rigidity , spasms , and seizures while the patient remains conscious during the episodes, often presenting with arching of the back (opisthotonos) . Recognizing these symptoms is crucial in diagnosing strychnine toxicity and differentiating it from other toxicological emergencies.
  • ➤ Strychnine poisoning
  • ➤ muscle rigidity
  • ➤ spasms
  • ➤ seizures
  • ➤ conscious
  • ➤ arching of the back (opisthotonos)

questions.text: A 25-year male presents after ingesting oxalic acid. He has severe burning pain in throat and difficulty breathing. His BP is normal but appears restless. Lab tests reveal metabolic acidosis. Most appropriate immediate intervention?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endotracheal intubation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of corrosive poisoning , the primary concern is ensuring airway patency and breathing . Immediate management should focus on securing the airway, often requiring endotracheal intubation , especially if there are signs of respiratory difficulty.
  • ➤ corrosive poisoning
  • ➤ airway patency
  • ➤ breathing
  • ➤ endotracheal intubation

questions.text: In OPC poisoning, treatment was done with atropine and pralidoxime. Hyperthermia occurs. What could be the cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Atropine Toxicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atropine toxicity can cause hyperthermia due to its anticholinergic effects, which inhibit sweating and increase body temperature. In the treatment of OPC poisoning , careful monitoring of atropine dosage is essential to avoid these toxic effects.
  • ➤ Atropine toxicity
  • ➤ hyperthermia
  • ➤ OPC poisoning

questions.text: A 28-year-old male arrives in the emergency department after being exposed to an unidentified toxic substance given to him by a friend. His symptoms include dry mouth, urinary retention, and constipation. During the examination, his pulse rate is recorded at 140 beats per minute, and his pupils are observed to be dilated. Which substance is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Belladona

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Belladonna (Atropa belladonna) and related plants cause anticholinergic toxicity , which manifests as dry mouth , urinary retention , tachycardia , and dilated pupils . Recognizing these signs is crucial for diagnosing anticholinergic poisoning and differentiating it from other toxic exposures like opioids or cholinergic agents.
  • ➤ Belladonna
  • ➤ anticholinergic toxicity
  • ➤ dry mouth
  • ➤ urinary retention
  • ➤ tachycardia
  • ➤ dilated pupils
